name: Hoi An
fun_fact: Fun fact: Only ONE family makes the authentic White Rose dumplings for the entire city - they've held this secret recipe for 130 years since their Chinese ancestors settled here. No matter where you eat White Rose in Hoi An, it all comes from the same kitchen! Similarly, true Cao Lau can only be made in Hoi An using water from the ancient Ba Le well.

hero_dishes.name: Cao Lau
hero_dishes.description: Hoi An's most mysterious dish - thick rice noodles with sliced pork, crispy pork rinds, rice crackers, peanuts, and local herbs. The secret: it MUST use water from the 9th-century Ba Le Cham well to treat the noodles.
hero_dishes.origin_story: This dish cannot be replicated outside Hoi An because authentic Cao Lau uses water from a specific ancient well and ash from local trees. Rumor has it only one local lady knows the exact recipe. Restaurants buy the noodles daily from the market.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street food stalls throughout Hoi An Ancient Town, Morning Glory Restaurant, local markets

hero_dishes.name: White Rose Dumplings (B√°nh Bao V·∫°c)
hero_dishes.description: Delicate shrimp dumplings shaped like white roses - steamed translucent rice paper filled with shrimp and spices. French colonials named them for their resemblance to white roses.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A Chinese family brought this recipe to Hoi An 130 years ago. Their descendants are the ONLY people who make these dumplings - every restaurant in Hoi An gets them from this one family! Like Cao Lau, the water must come from Ba Le well.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: White Rose Restaurant (533 Hai Ba Trung - the original family restaurant), Morning Glory, or anywhere in Hoi An (all from the same source!)

hero_dishes.name: Mi Quang
hero_dishes.description: Turmeric-infused rice noodles with light broth, fresh herbs, and meat or shrimp. The yellow color and complex spicing reflect Hoi An's spice trade history.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born from Hoi An's multicultural trading past - turmeric from India, noodle techniques from China, herbs from Vietnam. Each element tells the story of the ancient port.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street food vendors, Morning Glory Restaurant, local markets

hero_dishes.name: Com Ga Hoi An (Chicken Rice)
hero_dishes.description: Shredded chicken with turmeric rice and fresh herbs - Hoi An's comfort food that showcases the town's love of turmeric and aromatic herbs.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Influenced by the Chinese Hainanese chicken rice but made distinctly Vietnamese with local herbs and turmeric from the spice trade routes.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Com Ga Ba Buoi (famous chicken rice stall), street vendors in Ancient Town

signature_drinks.description: Bold, intense coffee (made with robusta beans containing double the caffeine of arabica) slowly dripped through a metal filter into sweetened condensed milk and ice. Rich, sweet, and incredibly strong.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Slowly, at sidewalk caf√©s, watching the world go by. The ritual is as important as the drink. Let the coffee drip completely before stirring - don't rush it.

signature_drinks.name: Bia Hoi (Fresh Beer)
signature_drinks.description: Light, crisp beer brewed daily without preservatives. Served from metal casks at roadside stalls for about 15 cents a glass.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: At plastic tables on the street, especially across the river with views of the old town. It's a social experience - Bia Hoi is about community, not just drinking. Hoi An is famous for having loads of bia hoi spots.

signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: As a special treat, sipped slowly to savor the silky egg cream floating on strong coffee

food_culture_notes: Hoi An was Southeast Asia's most important trading port from 15th-19th centuries
The cuisine blends Chinese, Japanese, Vietnamese, and European influences from centuries of trade
The Ancient Town is a UNESCO World Heritage Site with preserved 16th-18th century architecture
The monthly Lantern Festival (14th lunar day) transforms the town - electric lights go off and colorful lanterns light everything
Locals release paper lanterns on the Hoai River during full moons
The Japanese Covered Bridge (built 1593) is on the 20,000 VND note and connects old Japanese and Chinese quarters
Traditional wooden houses, assembly halls, and pagodas line the streets
Vietnam is the world's second-largest coffee exporter - coffee culture is a source of national pride

atmosphere: French colonial architecture mixed with Vietnamese
unique_modern: Thriving tailor shops (custom clothes in 24 hours)
Coffee culture blending tradition and Instagram aesthetics
